text: So, it's not a new thing for us to have two of these small words together.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Nos lo, te lo, me lo.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What we didn't see so far is having two words together, two of these small words together, where both of them begin with L.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: That's because in Spanish, when that happens, a phonetic change occurs.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, for example, if I wanted to say, I gave it to him, it should be le lo di.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But, and this isn't about grammar, it's about phonetics, it's about sound, Spanish doesn't like that.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Spanish doesn't like the sound of those two Ls together, le lo.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, where we would have le lo, les lo, les los, le los, any combination of le le together with these small words, the first one is going to turn into se.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But a totally different use, and it's not changing any meaning, it's just a phonetic issue.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, this means that le lo, les lo, become se lo.

text: So, how would you say, I gave it to him?

text: How would you say, I gave it to you guys, or to them?

text: So, it is really just a phonetic change.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It's got nothing to do with the different meanings that we saw for se, like himself and herself, that we saw before.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It's just a phonetic change because Spanish doesn't like having these two Ls together.

text: So, now is a good time to look at how we can make these clarifications, generally, not just in this structure, but generally.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, for example, how would you say, I gave him something?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, in this case, we might want to clarify as well because, of course, le di algo could mean I gave him something, I gave her something, I gave you, Fumel, something.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how do we make that clarification?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We repeat the whole sentence, and then we say afterwards, to him, to her.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, le di algo a él.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you clarify, I gave something to you, speaking Fumeli?

text: Good, le di algo a usted.

text: No, we don't get rid of that le, because we put a usted, which is excellent for the learner, because it means you don't have to worry about changing the structure of the sentence when you're clarifying, using this a to clarify, because you're repeating.

text: Now, we saw before, we didn't have this situation.

text: For example, we could say, he buys it for me, or we don't repeat the me there.

text: But with this a, with this a that we use to clarify, we will always repeat.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You don't have to go back and restructure, because you've made that clarification.

text: We can use it to clarify, but not just for the preposition to.

text: For example, if I say, me lo compra a mí, and I use this A to emphasize me.

text: So, this A is a bit special.

text: We're using it to clarify, and it can replace or represent other prepositions, other than to, which is its literal translation.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And because it has this special use, we are always repeating with A.

text: Whereas, as we saw before, with the other prepositions, we are not repeating.
